title: How to Prepare for a Blackout

steps.headline: Stock up on lighting.
Purchase a backup generator online or from any hardware store.
steps.description: Depending on the generator model you choose, these devices can power parts of or all of your home from several hours to more than a week.

steps.headline: Stock your pantry with non-perishable food.
steps.description: Items requiring refrigeration or a freezer will be the first to spoil if the power fails.

steps.headline: Purchase a battery-operated radio or television.
steps.description: These are essential for keeping up with the latest information.

steps.headline: Keep your cell phone charged.
steps.description: Landline phones may be effected by a power outage, which makes having a usable cell phone helpful if you need to call someone.

steps.headline: Store all of your supplies in an easily accessible place.
steps.description: This way, you don't have to waste time searching for them when you need them.

steps.headline: Keep ice packs in your freezer.
steps.description: If the blackout lasts for longer than an hour, use these ice packs to keep meat and other food products as fresh as possible. This should help you make do until the electricity is restored.

steps.headline: Use fluorescent tags that glow in the dark.
steps.description: These are available at certain stores. Place these tags at possible danger points in your home, so that anyone walking in the dark can find their way around easily without bumping into walls, furniture, etc.
